channel.title: Interleaved RSS Feed
channel.description: This is an interleaved feed of the most recent entries from each RSS source, skipping any feeds with errors.

item.title: U.S. durable-goods orders rise moderately in July ‚Äî excluding volatile transportation sector
item.description: Orders at U.S. factories for long-lasting goods, such as new cars or machinery, jumped 9.9% in July, beating a 4% forecast. Orders have risen in five of the last six months.

item.title: A 'man-made disaster' could make it trickier to buy or sell a home in some areas this fall, real estate expert says
item.description: Looming expiration for the largest U.S. flood insurance program may hold up some home sales this fall, just as the Federal Reserve is expected to cut interest rates.

item.title: Dow rallies 200 points to new record, completing comeback from early August rout: Live updates
item.description: The Dow rallied to a new record high after a winning week for stocks.

item.title: FAQ‚Äôs for $2,000 challenge

item.title: Activist Elliott lays out how to fix Southwest Airlines and its stock
item.description: Shares of Southwest Airlines Co. got a lift toward a six-week high Monday after activist investor Elliott Management sent a letter to shareholders explaining why the air carrier needs new leadership.

item.title: Harris campaign says it has raised $40 million since her convention speech
item.description: The windfall brings the total raised for Harris‚Äô election efforts to $540 million since President Joe Biden dropped out last month.

item.title: The end of a dream: What happens when an Olympian's career is over
item.description: "It's the one inevitability. It doesn't matter how successful you are as an athlete or how long or short your career is. Once you start, the one guarantee is that at some point it will stop," said Katherine Grainger, retired British rower and Chair of UK Sport.

item.title: Big growth trading just 5 contracts? (see how)

item.title: Low-income consumers are still struggling. Now the cracks are starting to show for higher-income ones, survey finds.
item.description: Mizuho said Monday its August consumer survey found that low-income consumers, who account for 22% of total U.S. household spending, are continuing to struggle. But the cracks were also starting to show for higher-income consumers.

item.title: Trump says Musk wouldn't have time to be in his White House cabinet, but could 'consult'
item.description: Elon Musk and Donald Trump have formed an unlikely alliance ahead of the 2024 election against Kamala Harris.

item.title: Who is Telegram founder Pavel Durov ‚Äî and why was he arrested?
item.description: The chief executive officer of Telegram, Pavel Durov, was arrested and placed in custody for alleged offenses related to the app, sources told AFP.

item.title: IBM closing research unit in China, Wall Street Journal reports
item.description: IBM is reportedly cutting 1,000 jobs after its revenue from China fell nearly 20% in 2023.

item.title: Boeing Starliner returning empty as NASA turns to SpaceX to bring astronauts back from ISS
item.description: Boeing will return its capsule from the International Space Station without the NASA astronauts that Starliner delivered to orbit.

item.title: Russia launches massive missile and drone attack on Ukraine, Kyiv says
item.description: Power cuts and water supply outages were reported in numerous places, including parts of Kyiv, as officials said the attack targeted critical infrastructure.

item.title: McKesson to acquire controlling stake in Core Ventures for $2.49 billion in cash
item.description: McKesson said it hopes to ‚Äúbring advanced treatments and improved care experiences to patients, while also reducing the overall cost of care.‚Äù

item.title: Dozens of colleges see financial aid turmoil impacting freshman class makeups
item.description: Education Secretary Miguel Cardona vows ‚Äúto do better‚Äù as administrators say this year‚Äôs FAFSA debacle is already leaving its mark on campuses.

item.title: The Israel-Hezbollah escalation has arrived. What next for the Middle East?
item.description: A series of cross-border attacks between Israel and Hezbollah over the weekend sparked fears of a wider regional conflict, but an "all-out war" appears to have been averted, for now.
